Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Oscar Varela at Utah State University.

General relativity and quantum field theory have traditionally been thought to be irreconcilable theories. The former governs the large-scale structure of the universe and is manifestly classical. The latter describes the fundamental interactions --- electromagnetic, weak, and strong --- that operate at a subatomic level. But, could it be possible that these two seemingly different theories were actually two different sides of the same coin? Could they be regarded as dual manifestations of an overarching set of physical principles? If this were the case, general relativity and quantum field theory would complement rather than conflict each other, as they would be equivalent, albeit with different applicability regimes. In his research, Professor Varela will develop aspects of this idea, which is commonly known as the so-called "AdS/CFT correspondence". This research advances the national interest by promoting the development of science in a fundamental direction, by developing relations among the laws of physics at deeper and deeper levels. It will also have broader impacts by providing training for junior physicists and by disseminating its results to the general public, especially to members of under-represented groups.

More technically, Professor Varela will study different aspects of the AdS/CFT correspondence with a focus in the supergravity regime where tighter control of the correspondence is attained. New tools will be introduced and developed to construct solutions to the supergravity equations that contain anti-de Sitter space. These methods will exploit the reformulations of higher-dimensional supergravities that make exceptional symmetries manifest, and will also utilize restricted tensor and duality hierarchies. Effective lower-dimensional supergravity theories with AdS vacua will be constructed and their embeddings into string theory elucidated. Finally, the field theory duals of those new string theory solutions will be investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Anti-deSitter/conformal field theory (AdS/CFT) correspondence or duality provides a potential solution to one of the most outstanding problems in theoretical high energy physics: the reconciliation of gravity with quantum field theory -the framework that encompasses the other three fundamental interactions. The correspondence conjectures the equivalence of string theory (a candidate theory of quantum gravity) formulated on Anti-deSitter space, and a specific class of quantum field theories, so-called conformal. The correspondence is usually called holographic, in the sense that gravitational effects on higher-dimensional Anti-deSitter space are equivalently captured, like in a hologram, by a lower-dimensional quantum field theory.

In a certain regime, string theory reduces to supergravity (an extension of Einstein's theory of general relativity) formulated in ten or eleven spacetime dimensions. It is in the supergravity regime where firm control on both sides of the correspondence is attained. Finding new solutions to the equations of ten- or eleven-dimensional supergravity that contain anti-deSitter space is, thus, crucial to extend the AdS/CFT correspondence into new applicability scenarios under controlled conditions.

In this project, new supergravity tools were introduced and developed to construct such solutions. Firstly, supergravity theories in lower dimensions were analysed and anti-deSitter solutions to those models constructed. Secondly, new ideas were developed to track those lower-dimensional solutions all the way up to ten and eleven-dimensions, thus obtaining new fully-fledged string theory solutions. Finally, the field theory duals of those new string theory solutions were determined and novel precision tests of the AdS/CFT correspondence were performed.

The intellectual merit of this award consisted in introducing new supergravity techniques to address the points outlined above. For example, one of these techniques provided a powerful new way of computing for the first time operator spectra of difficult conformal field theories at strong coupling. This solved a long-standing question in the field.

Also, this award has broader impacts on three fronts. Firstly, other research areas in both physics and mathematics may benefit from the results of this proposal in the long run. Secondly, educational and training aspects were an important component of the project. Indeed, the proposed research was carried out with a postdoctoral researcher and a graduate student within the Differential Geometry, Computer Algebra and Mathematical Physics (DGCAMP) group of Utah State University (USU). This is an interdisciplinary group composed of USU physicists and mathematicians at faculty, postdoctoral and graduate student level, with a focus on research and education. Thirdly, outreach activities were carried out. Specifically, a blog was maintained where the results of this project and other current topics in physics were be discussed in plain words for a broad audience. The blog specifically targeted the Spanish-speaking minorities.
